- download build
- start with: ./eclipse -console -consoleLog &

I get the following stack trace and Eclipse freezes. I have to kill the process. This all happens before the workspace chooser dialog. Might have to press Enter in the console to get it to happen.

java.io.IOException: Unknown error 512
        at java.io.FileInputStream.read(FileInputStream.java:229)
        at java.io.BufferedInputStream.read1(BufferedInputStream.java:265)
        at java.io.BufferedInputStream.read(BufferedInputStream.java:324)
        at java.io.FilterInputStream.read(FilterInputStream.java:134)
        at java.io.FilterInputStream.read(FilterInputStream.java:113)
        at sun.nio.cs.StreamDecoder$ConverterSD.implRead(StreamDecoder.java:352)
        at sun.nio.cs.StreamDecoder.read(StreamDecoder.java:250)
        at java.io.InputStreamReader.read(InputStreamReader.java:212)
        at java.io.BufferedReader.fill(BufferedReader.java:157)
        at java.io.BufferedReader.readLine(BufferedReader.java:320)
        at java.io.BufferedReader.readLine(BufferedReader.java:383)
        at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.FrameworkConsole.console(FrameworkConsole.java:273)
        at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.FrameworkConsole.run(FrameworkConsole.java:218)
        at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:803)

This maybe related to bug 192361.  I'm not sure why this is failing, but I am not sure what the expected behavior should be either.  If the process is run in the background then where will the console get its input from?  I suspect java (or maybe jni from the launcher) is getting confused when it tries to figure out what the input stream should be for a background process.

one workaround is to specify a port for the console.  For example

  ./eclipse -console 8082 -consoleLog &

Then telnet into the console for input

  telnet localhost 8082
